title: Will the Stock Market's 2021 Returns Crush 2020's?

title: Earnings Season Is About to Begin. Investors Are Already Looking Past it.
text: Investors will likely pay more attention to how management teams address the post-pandemic future. As long as optimism prevails, the stock market should hold up just fine.

text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average hit a record high despite the chaos of the past week. Why the rally could use a rest.

title: The Buffett Dividend Dogs Displayed For January

title: Jim Cramer's game plan for the trading week of Jan 11
text: With a new President taking office in less than two weeks, we may be more interested in what Biden says than in any individual company, the "Mad Money" host said.

title: December jobs number makes new stimulus checks more likely, Jim Cramer say
text: "Every disappointing jobs number like this one makes it more likely we'll get another round of government stimulus checks to help cushion the blow," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: December 2020 Jobs Report: Recovery Goes Into Reverse
text: U.S. employment fell by 140,000 in December as virus cases surged. Leisure and hospitality businesses were hit hard, but some industries showed growth.

title: Mohamed El-Erian: I've never seen markets ‘so disconnected' from economy
text: Allianz chief economic adviser Mohamed El-Erian shares his thoughts on the December jobs report, a ‘weakening' U.S. economy, bitcoin, the importance of the 10-year treasury yield and how markets are impacted by government spending. #FoxBusiness Subscribe to Fox Business!

title: US Indexes Close With Gains for the Week
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 31,097.97 on Friday with a gain of 56.84 points or 0.18%. The S&P 500 closed at 3,824.68 for a gain of 20.89 points or 0.55%.

title: Silver Linings Were Hard to Find in Dismal Jobs Report
text: The U.S. lost 140,000 jobs in December, the first net loss since April. But what about wages, and how were specific sectors impacted?

title: Markets aim to begin 2021 similar to how 2020 ended
text: By Mark Hackett Thoughts Markets are poised to begin 2021 similar to how 2020 ended, with a broad market rally. Last week saw a strong close to the year, with the S&P 500® Index touching its 33rd record close for 2020.

title: Carnival, Delta And 3 Other Big Names Ravaged By Shutdowns Report Earnings Next Week–Here's What To Expect

title: December Jobs Not As Bad As Headline Number
text: This morning's jobs report printed down 140,000 jobs, versus an estimate of 71,000 new jobs created. But revisions from October and November offset the loss with 135,000 added jobs.

title: Stock Market Today: Stocks, Bitcoin Keep Scrambling Over the Wall of Worry
text: The major indices pressed on despite a new low point in the COVID fight and a disappointing jobs report. Digital currency Bitcoin hit new breathtaking heights as well.

title: Investors are buying disruption stocks which can lead to a bubble, says Peter Cecchini
text: AlphaOmega Advisors Peter Cecchini says sentiment was likely to carry higher in 2021. He says investors are trying to buy disruptions such as Tesla or Moderna, which can fuel a bubble in markets.

title: Markets face a big week of news, with stimulus at the top of the list
text: Markets will stay laser-focused on the prospect for more fiscal stimulus in the busy week ahead.

title: Dow, S&P 500 rebound to all-time highs after Biden demands trillions of dollars in aid
text: US stocks closed at record highs on Friday to finish out the first week of trading in 2021. After the market reversed lower mid-day, stocks recovered as President-elect Joe Biden demanded for trillions of dollars in immediate further fiscal support, citing the weaker-than-expected jobs report. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 closed at record highs. President-elect Biden called for increasing direct payments to individuals after the US saw payrolls drop for the first time since April.

title: ‘We're in nosebleed territory' – three market analysts on where stocks head in 2021
text: Stocks are on track to end the first trading week of 2021 higher. Here are three experts with their market outlooks for 2021.

title: The December jobs report may be signaling a double-dip recession: Austan Goolsbee
text: #recession #coronavirus #doublediprecession Austan Goolsbee, Professor of Economics At the University of Chicago Booth School of Business and former Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers Under President Obama discusses why the December 2020 jobs report may be signaling a recession. title: U.S. stocks finish at records to book weekly gains despite December job losses
text: U.S. stocks finished at all-time highs on Friday, capping weekly gains for major equity benchmarks after a worse-than-expected employment report in December bolstered expectations for further fiscal stimulus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 57 points, or 0.2%, to end at 31,098, based on preliminary numbers.

title: The Fed: Consumer borrowing picks up in November but credit cards remain out-of-favor
text: Consumer borrowing picked up in November, but consumers continued to shy away from using their credit cards, the Federal Reserve said Friday.

title: Enormous pockets of speculation in the market: Ron Insana

text: Comments from senior Federal Reserve officials and recent minutes from the December meeting are giving encouragement to the bond bears.

title: Capitol Report: Biden calls for more relief ‘now' after disappointing jobs report
text: President-elect Joe Biden on Friday called for extra relief "now" after the latest U.S. jobs report showed losses for the first time in eight months, a reflection of the continued toll the coronavirus is taking on the economy.

text: CNBC's Kelly Evans breaks down the Federal Reserve's corporate debt relief with Sheila Bair, director at the Volcker Alliance and former FDIC chair, who called it "an economic dud" in the Wall Street Journal.

title: Benchmarks Hit Records in Dramatic First Week of 2021
text: Although the new year started slow, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJI) and S&P 500 Index (SPX) pulling back from record highs and logging their worst single-session drops since late October, the rest of the first week trading of 2021 went much smoother on Wall Street, all things considered.

title: Commodities Corner: Here's what's in store for industrial metals, after the 2020 rally for steel, iron ore and copper
text: Industrial metals have extended their 2020 rally into the new year, with finished steel prices trading near a record, iron ore, a feedstock for steel, holding ground near a nine-year high, and prices for copper at their highest since 2013. The gains are likely to extend through the first quarter, but prospects for some of the metals further out look brighter than others.

title: S&P 500 eases from record level as financials, industrials weigh
text: U.S. stocks lost momentum on Friday with the S&P 500 easing from record levels as losses in financials and industrials intensified after surging this week on hopes for further economic aid under a Democrat-controlled Congress.

title: Wall Street Week Ahead: As political risk fades, earnings may start to matter again
text: With uncertainties regarding U.S. elections fading, some investors expect company earnings and economic data to play a greater role in moving stock prices this year.

title: Economic Report: Restaurants lose 372,000 jobs in another crushing blow from the coronavirus across U.S.
text: Bars and restaurants got crushed again in December after the biggest coronavirus outbreak yet. Eating and drinking establishments lost 372,000 jobs last month, marking the first decline since April when they laid off a whopping 5.4 million people.

title: Dividend Stocks Won't Be Hurt By Rising Rates. Here's Why.

title: Economic Overview: January 1, 2021
text: The U.S. economy slowed into year-end as coronavirus cases surged following holiday gatherings and newly initiated shut-downs were enacted by various state governments. The slowdown will likely be reflected more clearly in the December and January numbers, as early Fall had the US economy on the rebound.

title: US Stock Market Indices Record New Highs, Treasury Bonds Waver

title: Clarida says Fed bond purchases to keep pace through the rest of the year
text: The Fed is buying at least $120 billion in month, split between a minimum $80 billion in Treasurys and $40 billion in mortgage-backed securities.

title: Bond Yields' Jump Could Be a Big Problem for Stocks
text: Continued rise boosts risks of inflation and higher borrowing costs, while making debt securities more alluring than stocks to income investors.
